S1.T1.caption: TABLE I: Summary of the Current State of the Art
S1.T1.table:
Multiple Access Method Compressed Model Updates? Client Energy Consumption? Impact of Communication Errors?
[18, 19, 20] Over-the-air computation ‚úó ‚úó analog communication with high SNR
[23, 21, 22] Over-the-air computation ‚úî ‚úó analog communication with high SNR
[4, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12] TDMA/FDMA ‚úó ‚úó ‚úó
[2, 3, 5, 6, 11] TDMA/FDMA ‚úó ‚úî ‚úó

This work TDMA/FDMA ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî
references: To reduce the communication overhead, [14, 15, 16, 17] incorporate the quantization, sparsification and error compensation schemes. However, these works do not consider the energy consumption and communication errors. Another line of works [18, 19, 20] adopt the over-the-air computation scheme for model updates aggregation to improve the communication efficiency. [21, 22, 23] further combine model updates compression schemes with over-the-air aggregation. While over-the-air computation mechanisms demonstrate advantages in terms of bandwidth efficiency, they usually require tight synchronization and CSI information at the workers side for power equalization. Besides, none of these works consider the energy consumption of the workers. A summary of the main differences between this work and the current state of the art can be found in Table I.

references: Table II and Table III show the testing accuracy and energy consumption of SignSGD with the proposed operation point and FedAVG with the optimal TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l}. It can be observed that SignSGD outperforms FedAVG in both testing accuracy and energy consumption. Moreover, we note that there is no existing method in literature that can obtain the optimal TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l} and the number of local iterations œÑùúè\tau for FedAVG.

references: In this subsection, the performance of Algorithm 2 is examined. We first consider the extreme case where each worker stores only training data from one label. We set Pm‚Äãi‚Äãn,m=0subscriptùëÉùëöùëñùëõùëö0P_{min,m}=0 W and Pm‚Äãa‚Äãx,m=0.05subscriptùëÉùëöùëéùë•ùëö0.05P_{max,m}=0.05 W for all the workers. Table IV and Table V show the testing accuracy and energy consumption of the learning algorithms, respectively. The time duration for each communication round is set to Tl=1.5subscriptùëáùëô1.5T_{l}=1.5s for both Algorithm 2 and SignSGD. For FedAVG, we examine the performance of different TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l}‚Äôs and present the results with the best testing accuracy. For SignSGD and FedAVG, we set the total training time Tt‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äãa‚Äãl=300subscriptùëáùë°ùëúùë°ùëéùëô300T_{total}=300s, while for Algorithm 2, we present the results with a total training time of Tt‚Äão‚Äãt‚Äãa‚Äãl=250subscriptùëáùë°ùëúùë°ùëéùëô250T_{total}=250s. For SignSGD and FedAVG, we first set the transmission power Pm=0.05‚ÄãWsubscriptùëÉùëö0.05ùëäP_{m}=0.05W for all the workers (such that the minimum outage probability can be achieved) and examine their performance given different CPU frequencies (i.e., 1 GHz, 2 GHz and 3 GHz). In addition to the pre-determined CPU frequency cases where the workers obtain their gradients before computing their outage probabilities, we also examined the scenario where each worker optimizes the CPU frequency given a pre-determined outage probability requirement po‚Äãu‚Äãt,m=0.1subscriptùëùùëúùë¢ùë°ùëö0.1p_{out,m}=0.1 for Algorithm 2 with fm‚Äãi‚Äãn,m=0.2subscriptùëìùëöùëñùëõùëö0.2f_{min,m}=0.2 GHz and fm‚Äãa‚Äãx,m=3subscriptùëìùëöùëéùë•ùëö3f_{max,m}=3 GHz. Correspondingly, the performance of SignSGD is examined in the same setting. For FedAVG with optimal TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l}, we note that the outage probabilities of the workers are larger than 0.1 for all the examined CPU frequencies. In this sense, adding the outage probability requirement essentially leads to the same results as Pm=Pm‚Äãa‚Äãx,m=0.05subscriptùëÉùëösubscriptùëÉùëöùëéùë•ùëö0.05P_{m}=P_{max,m}=0.05 W and fm=fm‚Äãa‚Äãx,m=3subscriptùëìùëösubscriptùëìùëöùëéùë•ùëö3f_{m}=f_{max,m}=3 GHz, given that the workers try their best to minimize their outage probabilities. It can be observed from Table IV and Table V that Algorithm 2 outperforms FedAVG and SignSGD in both testing accuracy and energy consumption given a shorter training time. That being said, Algorithm 2 improves the learning performance and reduces the energy consumption simultaneously, which demonstrates its effectiveness. Moreover, we note that the condition po‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äã(rm)‚â§mini‚Å°{12‚àíb‚Äã|‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíò(k))i|}subscriptùëùùëúùë¢ùë°subscriptùëüùëösubscriptùëñ12ùëè‚àásubscriptùêπùëösubscriptsuperscriptùíòùëòùëñp_{out}(r_{m})\leq\min_{i}\{\frac{1}{2}-b|\nabla F_{m}({\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\boldsymbol{w}}^{({\color[rgb]{0,0,0}k})})_{i}|\} may be violated for a pre-determined po‚Äãu‚Äãt,m=0.1subscriptùëùùëúùë¢ùë°ùëö0.1p_{out,m}=0.1. In this case, the pre-processing probabilities pmisuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëöùëñp_{m}^{i} and 1‚àípmi1superscriptsubscriptùëùùëöùëñ1-p_{m}^{i} in (34) may fall out of the range [0,1]01[0,1]. We round them to 1 if they are positive and 0 otherwise. Table IV and Table V show that the energy consumption of the workers can be further reduced by optimizing the CPU frequency fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m}‚Äôs with a negligible loss in testing accuracy.

references:
We also examine the impact of data heterogeneity (i.e., Œ±ùõº\alpha) in the Dirichlet distribution scheme. Table VI and Table VII compare the testing accuracy and the energy consumption of the learning algorithms, respectively, given fm=2subscriptùëìùëö2f_{m}=2 GHz for all the workers. It can be observed that the performance of SignSGD and FedAVG improves as Œ±ùõº\alpha
increases, which corresponds to more homogeneous data distribution. Meanwhile, Algorithm 2 outperforms SignSGD and FedAVG in both testing accuracy and energy consumption in all the examined scenarios, which demonstrates its effectiveness in the presence of different levels of data heterogeneity. Moreover, it is worth mentioning that the optimal TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l} and number of local iterations for FedAvg are different given different Œ±ùõº\alpha, which leads to different energy consumption.

references: For the homogeneous data distribution scenario, given the theoretically derived outage probability po‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äã(rm)subscriptùëùùëúùë¢ùë°subscriptùëüùëöp_{out}(r_{m}), we assume that the actual outage probability is uniformly distributed in the interval [po‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äã(rm),po‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äã(rm)√ó(1+Œî)]subscriptùëùùëúùë¢ùë°subscriptùëüùëösubscriptùëùùëúùë¢ùë°subscriptùëüùëö1Œî[p_{out}(r_{m}),p_{out}(r_{m})\times(1+\Delta)]. That being said, the channel conditions are worse than the ones that each worker uses for parameter configuration. We note that this is conservative since the performance of the learning algorithms is supposed to improve as the probability of outage decreases. Table VIII shows the testing accuracy of SignSGD with the configurations given by the solution of (17). The other parameters are the same as those in Section VII-A. It can be observed that the SignSGD with Œî‚àà{10%,30%,50%}Œîpercent10percent30percent50\Delta\in\{10\%,30\%,50\%\} achieves comparable performance in testing accuracy to the Œî=0Œî0\Delta=0 case. We note that, according to (19), the energy consumption is independent of ŒîŒî\Delta. Therefore, the energy consumption remains the same for different ŒîŒî\Delta.
